title: EastEnders star Ross Kemp 'proud' as he supports Poppy Appeal
text:
EastEnders star Ross Kemp throws support behind Poppy Appeal launch (Picture: PA)

EastEnders star Ross Kemp has thrown his support behind the Poppy Appeal.

The 55-year-old made an appearance at Kings Cross Station, in London, where he celebrated the launch with a number of celebs.

But there was one guest he made sure to keep close to his side.

Yes, 10-year-old Charlton Fleming was on hand to help dish out the pin badges, after his father Royal Marine Michael Taylor was killed in action in Afghanistan when the youngster was just 10-months-old.

Taking to Twitter, the actor shared a series of photos from the day, alongside a heartfelt caption.

He was joined by 10-year-old Charlton Fleming (Picture: PA)

He wrote: ‘Proud to be a part of the launch of the #PoppyAppeal with @PoppyLegion and @GCHQ today.

‘Great to catch up with @benshephard too! Buy a poppy and show your support.’

Ross isn’t the only A-Lister to get behind the 2019 campaign, as Rachel Riley has also helped to celebrate the thousands of volunteers who give up their free time for the Royal British Legion’s annual appeal.

‘I’ve gone undercover as part of the Royal British Legion and GCHQ’s Operation Poppy to highlight the hard work and dedication of the 40,000 Poppy Appeal collectors who give up their time each year, and to shine a spotlight on our armed forces who sacrifice so much to serve our country,’ she said.

He said he was proud to be part of the campaign (Picture: PA)

Rachel Riley has also got involved (Picture: PA)

The Countdown star was volunteering in Salford and met Alex Henshaw, who won Young Volunteer of the Year 2019 for the North West for his involvement in the Legion’s Riders branch.

Talking about her newfound friend, the soon-to-be mother-of-one said: ‘Every Poppy collector, like Alex, has a unique story to tell so please, look out for your local collector, make a donation and wear your poppy with pride.’

The Royal British Legion’s director of fundraising, Claire Rowcliffe, added: ‘Our undercover celebrities and the puzzles are a fun and engaging way for the public to get involved in this year’s Poppy Appeal launch, but there is a serious message at its heart.

‘Life for those in the armed forces community comes with a whole host of challenges and difficulties – from those that endure the daily sacrifice of being away from loved ones, to those carrying out roles that so often go unnoticed, such as at GCHQ.

‘This year is all about telling the hidden stories of our armed forces who provide an incredible service to our country in all kinds of ways, and telling the stories of the collectors who volunteer every year to show their support for them.’

The Royal British Legion’s annual Poppy Appeal takes place from 24 October until Armistice Day on 11 November.
